column3: How St. Piran at Perran Beach
column5: St. Piran, a pious man from South Ireland, performed numerous miracles but was cast into the sea with a millstone by jealous locals; miraculously, the storm abated and he drifted safely to Cornwall on the millstone. In Cornwall, he converted the locals to Christianity, discovered tin, significantly impacting the economy, and left a lasting legacy, particularly commemorated in the district of the Perran Sands where he lived and died.

St. David, born to a pious Welsh princess named Non and a barbarous chief, established a sanctuary known as 'The Monk's Dyke' on lands given by his remorseful grandfather, leading a peaceful life of conversion and miracles. Following his death, a cathedral was built in his honor in the city of St. Davids, a unique and picturesque location on the Welsh coast that visitors can still explore today.

St. Edmund, King of East Anglia, was captured by the Danes in 870 after refusing to renounce his Christian faith. He was tied to an oak tree, beaten, shot with arrows, and beheadedâ€”his head later miraculously found guarded by a wolf.
It is said that this was St. Levan's favourite seat; and one day cracked it in two with a blow from his staff and uttered a prophecy.
